Column Comment.0: ANALYSIS IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a sample analysis. Various types ofanalysis may be conducted on a sample. Samples may be derived from lithologiccuttings, fluid collection etc.
Column Comment.1: ANALYSIS SOURCE: The source that the analysis came from, this could be a labtechnician, a lab, a company, a government agency, etc.
Column Comment.2: ELEMENTAL ANALYSIS OBSERVATION NUMBER: A Unique observation numberfor the gas elemental analysis.
Column Comment.3: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y or N flag indicating whether this row of data is currentlyeither active/valid (Y) or inactive/invalid (N).
Column Comment.4: ASH ELEMENT: The value of the ash in the sample as per the elemental analysis.This value can vary pending on the original unit of measure. For example, if theoriginal unit of measure is ppm the value is the quantity of ash, or if the original unit ofmeasure is g/mol the value is concentration of ash, etc.
Column Comment.6: CARBON ELEMENT: The value of the carbon in the sample as per the elementalanalysis. This value can vary pending on the original unit of measure. For example, ifthe original unit of measure is ppm the value is the quantity of carbon, or if theoriginalunit of measure is g/mol the value is concentration of carbon, etc.
Column Comment.8: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.9: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.10: IRON ELEMENT: The value of the iron in the sample as per the elemental analysis.This value can vary pending on the original unit of measure. For example, if theoriginal unit of measure is ppm the value is the quantity of iron, or if the original unitofmeasure is g/mol the value is concentration of iron, etc.
Column Comment.12: HYDROGEN ELEMENT: The value of the hydrogen in the sample as per theelemental analysis. This value can vary pending on the original unit of measure. Forexample, if the original unit of measure is ppm the value is the quantity of hydrogenor if the original unit of measure is g/mol the value is concentration of hydrogen etc.
Column Comment.14: ANALYSIS MEASUREMENT TYPE: A list of valid measurement types. ANL QCVALID MEASURE lists which measurement types are valid for various types ofanalysis, and what valid ranges for the values should be. In analysis detail tables,ensure that you have selected a measurement type that is appropriate for the type ofstudy.
Column Comment.15: NICKEL ELEMENT: The value of the nickel in the sample as per the elementalanalysis. This value can vary pending on the original unit of measure. For example, ifthe original unit of measure is ppm the value is the quantity of nickel, or if the originalunit of measure is g/mol the value is concentration of nickel, etc.
Column Comment.17: NITROGEN ELEMENT: The value of the nitrogen in the sample as per the elementalanalysis. This value can vary pending on the original unit of measure. For example, ifthe original unit of measure is ppm the value is the quantity of nitrogen, or if theoriginal unit of measure is g/mol the value is concentration of nitrogen, etc.
Column Comment.19: OXYGEN ELEMENT: The value of the oxygen in the sample as per the elementalanalysis. This value can vary pending on the original unit of measure. For example, ifthe original unit of measure is ppm the value is the quantity of oxygen, or if theoriginalunit of measure is g/mol the value is concentration of oxygen, etc.
Column Comment.21: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.22: PROBLEM INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not there is a problem withthe step. If a yes flag is indicated, additional information regarding the problemshould be noted in the table ANL_PROBLEM.
Column Comment.23: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.24: REPORTED HYDROGEN TO CARBON RATIO: The reported hydrogen to carbonratio as per the elemental analysis.
Column Comment.26: REPORTED NICKEL TO CARBON RATIO: The reported nickel to carbon ratio asper the elemental analysis.
Column Comment.28: REPORTED NITROGEN TO CARBON RATIO: The reported nitrogen to carbon ratioas per the elemental analysis.
Column Comment.30: REPORTED OXYGEN TO CARBON RATIO: The reported oxygen to carbon ratio asper the elemental analysis.
Column Comment.32: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.33: STEP SEQUENCE NUMBER: A unique number indicating the sequence of the stepamong other steps in the preparation and processing of the sample. This column is asufficient method to keep track of what is done in the sample analysis. However, ifthe requirement for more complicated tracking such as two steps occurringsimultaneously or if steps are needed to be added to the initial procedure, use thetwo columns STEP_SEQ_NO1 and STEP_SEQ_NO2 in the tableANL_STEP_XREF.
Column Comment.34: SULFUR ELEMENT: The value of the sulfur in the sample as per the elementalanalysis. This value can vary pending on the original unit of measure. For example, ifthe original unit of measure is ppm the value is the quantity of sulfur, or if theoriginalunit of measure is g/mol the value is concentration of sulfur, etc.
Column Comment.36: VANADIUM ELEMENT: The value of the vanadium in the sample as per theelemental analysis. This value can vary pending on the original unit of measure. Forexample, if the original unit of measure is ppm the value is the quantity of vanadium,or if the original unit of measure is g/mol the value is concentration of vanadium, etc.
Column Comment.38: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.39: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.40: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.41: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.42: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.43: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.44: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
